title: Rey Commission
text:
The Rey Commission is the <a href="European%20Commission">European Commission</a> that held office from 2 July 1967 to 30 June 1970. Its president was <a href="Jean%20Rey%20%28politician%29">Jean Rey</a>.
Work.
It was the first commission of the <a href="Merger%20Treaty">merged</a> <a href="European%20Economic%20Community">European Communities</a>. It was the successor to the <a href="Hallstein%20Commission">Hallstein Commission</a> and was succeeded by the <a href="Malfatti%20Commission">Malfatti Commission</a>. The commission worked to reinforce the <a href="Institutions%20of%20the%20European%20Union">Communities' institutions</a> and increase the powers of the <a href="European%20Parliament">European Parliament</a>. It also campaigned for an elected parliament, which was achieved later in 1979. It oversaw the competition of the <a href="customs%20union">customs union</a> in 1968.
Rey played an important role the <a href="List%20of%20European%20Councils">Summit of The Hague</a> in 1969, where the European leaders decided to relaunch European integration with two new initiatives: on the one hand, <a href="Economic%20and%20Monetary%20Union%20of%20the%20European%20Union">Economic and Monetary Union of the European Union</a> (EMU), and on the other hand, <a href="European%20Political%20Cooperation">European Political Cooperation</a> (EPC), which foreshadow the <a href="euro">euro</a> and the <a href="Common%20Foreign%20and%20Security%20Policy">Common Foreign and Security Policy</a> of the <a href="European%20Union">European Union</a> today. 
Finally, in 1970, the last year of this mandate, Rey managed to win the European governments' support for his proposal to give the Community "own resources". This meant that the EEC no longer depended exclusively on contributions by the member states, but could complete these with revenues from customs duties, levies on agricultural products from outside the EEC, in addition to a share of the VAT revenue.
Membership.
The commission was composed of 14 members, 3 from Italy, West Germany, and France, 2 from Belgium and the Netherlands and 1 from Luxembourg.
